titlestmt.titleproper: Nelson A. Rockefeller Vice Presidential records, Video Recordings, Series 20
A Guide to the Nelson A. Rockefeller Vice Presidential records, Video Recordings, Series 20 FA798

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-04-21 00:05:22 -0400.

did.unittitle: Nelson A. Rockefeller Vice Presidential records Video Recordings, Series 20

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Transcripts and sound recordings of the Senate Rules Committee hearings on Nelson A. Rockefeller's Vice Presidential nomination, as well as other related documents, are located in Nelson A. Rockefeller vice presidential records, New York Office, Series 10 (FA380).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains 64 videotapes that relate to Nelson A. Rockefeller's term as United States Vice President.

These tapes include: the 1976 Moreland Act Commission hearings on New York State Nursing Home corruption; the 1974 Senate Rules Committee hearings on Rockefeller's Vice Presential nomination; and the confirmation of Nelson A. Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Nursing Home Hearings - Moreland Act Commission - Tape 22
Nursing Home Hearings - Moreland Act Commission - Tape 23
Nursing Home Hearings - Moreland Act Commission - Tape 24
Nursing Home Hearings - Moreland Act Commission - Tape 25
Nursing Home Hearings - Moreland Act Commission - Tape 26
Thursday News Coverage of Announcement to Call Nelson A. Rockefeller to Testify and Interview with Morris B. Abram

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Various news reports discussing the Moreland Act Commission's request for Vice President Nelson Rockefeller to testify. Includes: "The Nursing Home Scandals: A Conversation with Morris Abram," a 30-minute interview with the Chairman of the Moreland Act Commission, broadcast on Channel 13.

did.unittitle: Moreland Act Commission: The Final Report - Channel 13

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interviewer Robert Sam Anson interviews Morris B. Abram. They summarize and discuss outcomes from the Moreland Act Commission's 15-month investigation into corruption in the nursing home industry in New York.

did.unittitle: Compilation of News Broadcasts: Nelson A. Rockefeller Vice Presidential Hearings and Today Show Interview with Barbara Walters (NBC-TV)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Various televised new broadcasts reporting on Nelson A. Rockefeller's Vice Presidential nomination hearings. Includes footage of Nelson Rockefeller answering Senate questions related to his divestiture of assets, President Ford's pardoning of Richard Nixon, the Attica prison riots, and the loan of money to NY/NJ Port Authority Chairman William Ronan. Tape concludes at 11:45 with complete NBC-TV Today Show interview between Rockefeller and Barbara Walters.

did.unittitle: Washington: Senate Hearings on Nelson Rockefeller - Day One

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Special PBS-TV report hosted by Jim Leher (National Public Affairs Center for Television. Political analysts Richard Reeves of New York Magazine and author Neal Pierce discuss Nelson A. Rockefeller's finacial assets and family's influences. Leher provides a synposis of the topics that were covered during Day One of Senate questioning. Includes footage from hearings.

did.unittitle: Senate Rules Committee: Nelson A. Rockefeller's Vice Presidential Hearings - Day One (Tape 4)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tape begins with Nelson Rockefeller giving a statement (ending only recorded). Rockefeller responds to Senator Howard Cannon's questions regarding Ford's pardon of Nixon, and what would his position be toward a pardon should Rockefeller become President. Also, given the economic power of the Rockefeller family, Cannon questions "How can you conduct yourself in office in a manner that would avoid even the appearance of conflict of interest." Rockefeller discusses Rockefeller Foundation and the Rockefeller Brothers Fund. Nelson A. Rockefeller's annual income and income tax paid for each year beginning in the 1960s is discussed in detail. Senator Claiborne Pell continues "conflict of interest" questioning and discusses Rockefeller's past quotes about not wanting to be Vice President. Tape concludes with Senator Hugh Scott deriding Congress for not acting quicker on Vice Presidential confirmation hearings. Happy Rockefeller can be seen in the audience.

did.unittitle: Senate Rules Committee: Nelson A. Rockefeller's Vice Presidential Hearings - Day One (Tape 5)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tape begins with Senator Hugh Scott continuing questioning. Rockefeller speaks about the need for a Free Press and his relationship with labor. Senator Robert Byrd asks about his "considerable wealth" and what assurances the American people could have that his Vice Presidency won't enrich the "Rockefeller empire." Rockefeller speaks about his investments and those of his brothers. After breaking for recess, Senator Robert Byrd begins questioning by asking him about the pardoning powers of the President and about Rockefeller's wealth. Liberty Lobby allegations and Rockefeller's tax returns are detailed as well as his involvement with Bilderberg. Senator James Allen asks if Rockefeller has moved "philosophically to the Right." Rockefeller responds by discussing his actions with regard to Welfare and the drug control laws he enacted.

did.unittitle: Senate Rules Committee: Nelson A. Rockefeller's Vice Presidential Hearings - Day One (Tape 6)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Senator Mark Hatfield begins questioning. Rockefeller discusses economic topics: inflation, unemployment, balancing the Federal budget, increasing taxes. Rockefeller next discusses his views on the role of the Central Intelligence Agency.

Senator Harrison Williams begins questioning. Rockefeller discusses the 1971 lawsuit brought against him by the New York Civil Liberty Union, his thoughts regarding Separation of Powers and Executive Priviledge, and about his actions during the Watergate crisis. Senator Howard Cannon asks about the Rockefeller trusts increased capital gains in 1970 and why this resulted in Nelson Rockefeller paying no personal income tax that year. Rockefeller reports how he learned he was Ford's Vice Presidential nominee and Ford's phone call to Nixon telling him of this decision. Rockefeller also explains why he had been requesting a Grumman aircraft defense contract for New York. Senator Marlow Cook details the monetary amounts of family Foundations and Rockefeller Center. Nelson Rockefeller states that these should not be grouped into one category because Rockefeller Center is a business.

did.unittitle: Senate Rules Committee: Nelson A. Rockefeller's Vice Presidential Hearings - Day Two (Tape 7)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tape begins with special PBS-TV report: "Washington: Senate Hearings on Nelson Rockefeller," hosted by Jim Leher of National Public Affairs Center for Television (NPACT). Paul Duke(NPACT) and Richard Reeves from New York Magazine report on Rockefeller and his role as governor. Carolyn Lewis reports on Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller's 1972 lobbying for a Grumman aircraft defense contract for New York. Leher provides a synposis of what topics were covered during Day Two of Senate questioning.

Tape continues with Day Two of Senate Hearings: Senator Howard Cannon begins by reading a prepared statement regarding the three major national television network's decision not to "live" broadcast the hearings. Nelson Rockefeller begins by supplementing his answers to certain questions from the previous day, particulary about capital gains and his income taxes, the worth of Rockefeller Center, and the ACLU lawsuit.

Senator Robert Byrd questions Rockefeller about his wealth and influence, stating he disregards these attributes as being "a myth." Rockefeller responds, and speaks to Byrd's next question regarding the recent energy crisis and the role oil companies played.
Senator Robert Griffin asks about the Attica prison riots. Rockefeller speaks at length about this event and prison reform.

Senator James Allen questions why men of great wealth in politics tend to take a liberal stance. Rockefeller discusses his political philosophies, particularly in regard to American incomes and the distribution of wealth. He discusses his accomplishments with increased enrollment in State University of New York schools (SUNY), and concludes by talking about his capacity to balance business interest and national interest.

did.unittitle: Senate Rules Committee: Nelson A. Rockefeller's Vice Presidential Hearings - Day Two (Tape 8)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Senator Mark Hatfield asks about potential conflict of interest and Nelson Rockefeller states that there cannot be conflict of interest if a person takes his/her oath of office seriously. Rockefeller answers questions regarding the current housing crisis and questions regrding mass transit, in particular the idea of using Highway Trust funds for mass transit construction. Rockefeller speaks about how to help restore the American people's confidence in their political system, and the important role in using the medium of television to communicate.

Senator Harrison Williams begins questioning. Rockefeller answers questions regarding mass transportation, the current depression in the construction industry, and the needs of people and families affected by mental disabilities.

Senator Howard Cannon clarifies facts about the Grumman aircraft contract and Rockefeller speaks more about that deal. Cannon continues his questioning, asking about pardons. Rockefeller discusses his views about whether Nixon should be prosecuted, reflects on his commuting Lyman Judson Morehouse's conviction in 1960s, and provides more answers in regard to the Attica prisoner's demand for amnesty.
Tape ends with Senate Rules Committee breaking for midday reccess.

did.unittitle: Senate Rules Committee: Nelson A. Rockefeller's Vice Presidential Hearings - Day Two (Tape 9)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tape begins post-midday recess.

Senator Mark Hatfield asks about Rockefeller's relationship with his income. Rockefeller respondds by discussing his upbringing as a boy, learning the value of money, receiving an allowance and creating an annual budget. He speaks about his current money-related procedures.

Nelson Rockefeller answers Senator Claiborne Pell's questions about where Rockefeller plans to place his personal and official papers, the plans for a 1976 Bicentennial celebration, public finacing of campaigns for federal office, budget reductions, and the United State's relationship with Cuba.
Senator James Allen asks about the minimum tax for the wealthy.

Rockefeller speaks at length about forced school busing of students to acheive racial balance and the desegregation of public schools. Senator Allen asks Rockefeller to discuss his past comments regarding voluntary prayer in public schools. Rockefeller asks to be able to review his past comments and would answer this question at a later time.
Senator Hugh Scott reads for the record a letter he has drafted recommending further funding to the Public Broadcasting System (PBS) and commended PBS for their coverage of these hearings.

Senator Marlow Cook relates additional details regarding the Gumman aircraft deal. Rockefeller answers questions about limiting campaign financing, time limit on campaigning, and financial contributions by family members.
Rockefeller discusses his views on gun control and his record on gun control as governor of New York. He speaks about his various residencies and the needed security.
Cook asks about the role Rockefeller envisions for himself in regard to international affairs and his relationship with Secretary of State Henry Kissinger.

Senator Byrd questions Rockefeller regarding his views on continuing the process of impeachment to reveal all the facts pertaining to Watergate. Byrd voices his concern that the agreement Nixon entered into is witholding information to the public and Nixon may destroy certain documents and tapes.
